data.title: Rotation matrix multiplication order should be ZYX
Adapt overlooked instances of zero-based column numbers
Only show AnimationEditor automatically when an Animplayer is selected.
data.body:
Previous behaviour was to show it when an AnimationPlayer has been detected in the scene, now you actually have to select it.
Fixes #6213

data.title: Re-Allow absolute paths, make them behave correctly
data.body:
This PR reverts #6702 and closes #6801 .

It also provide a fix that will prevent an absolute path to be misinterpreted as a resource path (which keeps #3106 and #4280 closed since it should not be misleading anymore).
I tested this with absolute paths on Windows and Linux, all is working on my side.

Regarding the `local://` path, apparently is used inside XML representation for resources saved inside the scene file (eg. CollisionShape2D). So I left it untouched.

Example content of XML scene

```
        <resource type="CircleShape2D" path="local://2">
                <real name="custom_solver_bias"> 0 </real>
                <real name="radius"> 11.5 </real>

        </resource>
```

data.title: Add/expose VisualServer::get_default_clear_color()
find_node() for instanced nodes is counterintuitive
data.body:
Current signature is `Node find_node( String mask, bool recursive=true, bool owned=true )`.

In my scripts when I have to find a node whose path can change a lot during development and has a unique name, I try to find it with `get_tree().get_root().find_node("node_name")`.

A lot of times that doesn't work because the target node is instanced (not owned) and the default value of `owned` if **true**. What's the rationale behind that? Wouldn't a more universal solution be to default it to **false**?

It often takes me some minutes to figure out what's happening. What's more, if a node which is formerly there as itself is later saved as its own scene and instanced, it suddenly becomes non-findable without editing the code.

Doesn't Godot 3.0 constitute a good chance to change that default value?

data.title: CollisionShape don't work for scenes that are extending CollisionObject
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 x64
Godot 2.1 x64 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
 Inherited scenes based on a imported model/scene with the root node set to Rigid Body on import, will not receive collision.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Import a scene/character model and choose the custom import type set to a Rigid Body type as the root node. then create an Inherited scene based on the imported model/scene. Rig the Inherited scene with colliders and proceed to test collision.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I found that a work around is to first rig the base scene with colliders then save the scene. then you can delete the colliders from the base scene which magically makes the inherited scene know what a collider is. I've tested using Rigid Body node but I assume this bug probably extends to other Physics bodies too.
Something else I found weird was that if you instance the base scene and the inherited scene into another scene. if both the base scene and Inherited has a collider then you remove the collider from the base scene but keep the collider on the inherited scene. the base scene looks as if it inherits the collider from the inherited scene. fun stuff once you see how these bugs are so broken.

data.title: Add "button_selected" signal to ButtonGroup
data.body: easy to catch selected button changed, like `ButtonArray`

data.title: ButtonArray fixes and improvements
data.body:
When you mouse out of a button array - especially if horizontally for VButtonArray or vertically for HButtonArray - the hover status wouldn't reset.

Also, the position of the text didn't take into account the stylebox's content margins. This change follows the behaviour used in Button.

And while I was at it, I implemented support for tooltips, fixing #6597. With the use of default values it should be backwards compatible.

data.title: Expose resizable property of GraphNode in inspector
data.body: so, can make a resizable `GraphNode` scene without script to make it resizable.

data.title: Fix access to local file system with "local://" prefix
data.body:
Apparently the `"local://"` prefix was not handled properly by `DirAccess` and `FileAccess` classes.
This prevented the user from accessing the file system from script since #6702 

dir_access and file_access classes now properly remove "local:/"
prefix when accessing the file system.

Closes #6801 .

data.title: Setting direction of Particles2D through GDscript uses degrees and not radians
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot v2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

`Particles2D.set_param(Particles2D.PARAM_GRAVITY_DIRECTION, angle)`
requires `angle` to be in degrees and not in radians (as stated in help)
The same holds for `PARAM_DIRECTION`.

data.title: Added small modification on gdscript parser to allow users insert '+' before variables
data.body: Just modified the gdscript parser to allow users to insert a '+' before a variable value; it is mathematically redundant, but is not wrong, and sometimes it is visually useful, like when a variable is relative-to-something ("move(+5)").

data.title: local:// totally broken in load()
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
linux x11 HEAD (12843167cacf3bacca32c29b7ea8b4426392bad0)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
load fails on any local:// path
since some recent update load no longer works on absolute paths without prepending local:// however the big problem is that local:// doesn't seem to work either.  My server just lost its only way to access external enduser-supplied resources (which is not part of the project nor its hidden 'savegame' directory which is already broken due to #6047 if any symlinks occur along user://'s real directory path [I was also using absolute paths to work around #6047 via OS.get_data_dir()]).  Now all means of loading external files are gone!!!

**Steps to reproduce:**
![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1862162/19324122/deb61c98-9074-11e6-92fd-b3946dc1a462.png)

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
see _ready() in the screenshot (it's two lines and a sample dir sturcture to test with is shown)
duplicate with:

`sudo mkdir /test`
`sudo ln -s /test /symtest`
`sudo chown me:me /test`
`sudo chown -h me:me /symtest`
(where me is the user you run godot apps with)
`echo -e "extends Node\n\nfunc _ready():\n\tpass\n" >/test/test1.gd`
`cp /test/test1.gd /test/test2.gd`

in Godot:

```
func _ready():
    var a=load("local://test/test1.gd")
    var b=load("local://symtest/test2.gd")
```

data.title: Preload function would have to accept a  constant string parameter as input.
data.body:
**Preload function would have to accept a  constant string parameter as input.**

```
const WARM_UP_STATE = "res://scenes/states/warm_up/warm_up.tscn"

func _go():
    current_state = preload(WARM_UP_STATE).instance()
    level.add_child(current_state)

```

> res://scenes/levels/level_01/src/node2d_state_manager.gd:23  - Parse Error: expected string constant as 'preload' argument.

data.title: Changing scene tabs is an undo-able action (Or, undo is not locked to current scene)
data.body:
_Bugsquad edit:_ **TL;DR:** UndoRedo should work per-scene, having it undo stuff in all open scenes is very counter-intuitive and provides a bad UX.

---

While under the effect of issue #6772 and pressing the undo shortcut more than I should, I noticed opening another scene tab is somehow an event that counts towards undo. While this could be subjected to discussion, it seems like a wrong thing to do, as one expects the undo buffer to be contextual to the currently selected scene. Not to mention spurious events can push potentially important changes from the undo stack.

As further testing, I made a number of changes in separate scenes, mashing undo proceeded to do the entire sequence in reverse instead of undoing the changes in the scene I had selected, including changing scenes. Making some memory of things, it explains some unexpected effects I've encountered during longer work sessions but I didn't quite think of it at the time.

Why this can be problematic:
Say I have a scene "1" that is something like a visual effect, like a explosion.
1) I make two changes to "1" and seem satisfied with the result.
2) I open a scene "2" and include "1" in it. (at least 1-2 changes)
3) I make a last-minute change to "1"
4) I run the project, but I don't like how "1" looks like in action. So I decide to undo changes.
5) I undo twice, suddenly I am back to "2"
6) I keep undoing, and all changes to "2" are undone before I can reach "1" again.
7) I have undone the changes in "1", but as a result I erased all changes in "2".

This presents a large number of small-to-grave issues during the workflow:
1) It requires to mentally keep track of what scenes have been undone, and fix all "unwanted" undos (and with changes the "redo" buffer becomes nullified)
2) In case the changes become too difficult to undo, it requires a copy to restore or a version control (as in git) commit to revert to. While it's good practice to have such things, it's not always readily available, specially if it's a big change or a thing requiring several small tweaks, or some change done by pure chance (it happens). Note that for changes to be shown in the main project files have to be saved, so a basic reverting stops becoming an option every time the project is run. (read: not every scene does what one wants individually)
3) Having to restore the changes requires interrupting your workflow to restore the file.
4) If the file was created recently and there's no backup or recent commit, well, it might be impossible to restore to a "proper" point and has to be remade from scratch.

While one can argue that such potential mistakes can be avoided by being super careful, accidents/oversights/distractions happen. We are human after all. And projects can grow pretty large with a lot of files being juggled and changed all at once, or having to step away from the computer and forgetting you made change X in file Y.

data.title: Default clear color not applied on some projects.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 stable, Windows 8.1, Intel HD4600.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In some projects the new clear color is applied only in editor.

In the other projects the new clear color is applied only in the running game. After a restart the color is applied in the editor too, as expected.

**Steps to reproduce:**
In the "SAT collision test" demo set another default clear color.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
The "SAT collision test" official demo  ;)

data.title: EditorPlugin - "Error: set_persisting" when deactivated.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 7, build from Sept 12th

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When you set an editor plugin to be "inactive" in Project Settings, it gives a the following error in the console: 

> ERROR: set_persisting: Condition '  !props.has(p_name) ' is true. 
>     At: core/globals.cpp:100

I thought it was something I messed up with my own plugin, but it happens for every plugin I've tried, including all three of the official ones (custom dock, import plugin, and node). I tested them in a new, empty project. 

It doesn't crash the editor or cause any noticeable issues though, should I just ignore this?

data.title: add a new git label to mark back-portable cherry-pickable bug fixes for 2.x ?
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

I know that the plan is to give-up 2.2 and to release some 2.1.x till 3.1 is usable.

Though, even after 2.1.x will be abandoned by the devteam in favor of 3.x, there will still be some game-developers that will continue to maintain the 2.x games they have already released as part of their "customer care".

Even though the dev-team have spent lot of time, energy and love on 2.x, it might still exhibit some issues for which a fix will be released during the 3.x era. 

I'm aware that asking for the dev-team to provide LTS for 2.x is not a reasonable idea, and that if one wants LTS for 2.x, one will have to do it by oneself.

Though, maybe would-it possible to add some sort of git tags to mark issues and PRs that could or should be back-ported or cherry-picked to 2.x ?

This way, it would be easier to "unofficially" maintain 2.x even after the dev-team stops releasing official 2.1.x.
It would be some sort of "light-weight DIY LTS".

what do you think ?

**Steps to reproduce:**

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
